articles.title: Cytoscape.js: Graph/Network Visualization and Analysis Library
articles.description: Handy if you need to model and/or visualize relational data, like biological data or social networks. There are many demos to enjoy here. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Max Franz

articles.title: Announcing TypeScript 5.4 Beta
articles.description: TypeScript gains Object.groupBy and Map.groupBy, a new NoInfer<T> utility type is introduced to stop TypeScript from digging in to match against inner types during inference, and lots of smaller bits and pieces covered in this lengthy post. The final release is expected in March.
articles.author: Daniel Rosenwasser

articles.title: Deno 1.40: Now with the Temporal API
articles.description: Most releases of the Deno JS runtime seem significant lately, but 1.40’s implementation of the Temporal API, decorators, and more WebGPU features ups the ante on the path to v2.
articles.author: The Deno Team

articles.title: Take a Qwik Break from React with Astro
articles.description: Paul Scanlon compares React to Qwik using several examples and concludes that Qwik is at least worth exploring as a React alternative.
articles.author: Paul Scanlon

articles.title: Import Assertions and Import Attributes
articles.description: Shu-yu Guo, of both TC39 and the V8 team at Google, explains how import assertions matured into import attributes and are enabled by default in V8 v12.3.
articles.author: Shu-yu Guo (V8)

articles.title: A Next.js App Router Migration: The Good, Bad, and Ugly
articles.description: A team rebuilt their main dashboard from scratch using a modern Next.js approach and here’s some of what they encountered, good and bad, before concluding that they wish they’d considered Remix instead.
articles.author: Brandon Bayer (Flightcontrol)

articles.title: Squeezing the Last Bit of JS Performance for my Automation Game
articles.description: The author is building CivIdle, a casual ‘idle’ civilization building game, using Pixi.JS. As an idle game, it needs to simulate time that passed behind the scenes which meant a lot of optimization was in order.
articles.author: Ruoyu Sun

articles.title: Starting and Publishing a Library: The Modern Way
articles.description: A walk through the steps involved in creating and packaging a library, publishing a package, adding testing, and automatically publishing it all to the NPM registry.
articles.author: Tamás Sallai

articles.title: How to Test Web Bluetooth with Puppeteer
articles.description: Use Puppeteer to test features that use the Web Bluetooth API in Chrome.
articles.author: Masso and Beaufort

articles.title: Labyrinthos.js: A Procedural Generator for Mazes, Etc.
articles.description: The interactive demo on the homepage will give you the basic idea, but the library implements a variety of algorithms for creating mazes and terrain, including the use of Perlin noise, growing trees, spiral backtracking, and more. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Yantra Works

articles.title: React Resizable Panels: Components for Resizable Panels
articles.description: If you want users to be able to resize content panels with dividers, try this. The site has many code-based examples showing off the features. v2 supports resizing multiple intersecting panels at once. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Brian Vaughn

articles.title: Husky 9: Git Hooks Made Easier
articles.description: Husky provides a structured way to use git hooks to do things like auto-lint your commit messages or code, and run tests upon committing or pushing. v9 makes setting it up and adding hooks much easier.
articles.author: typicode

articles.title: David UI Angular 1.0: Tailwind + Angular Components Libary
articles.description: There are seventeen components so far, covering things like sliders, buttons, notification alerts, and common form elements. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Creative Tim

articles.title: React Datepicker 6.0: A Simple Date Picker Component
articles.description: I can’t remember the last time I saw so many code examples on a homepage :-)
articles.author: HackerOne

articles.title: goja: An ECMAScript/JavaScript Engine in Pure Go(lang)
articles.description: A way to add JavaScript-based scripting functionality to apps written in the Go language that doesn’t involve integrating a larger, external JavaScript engine.
articles.author: Dmitry Panov

articles.title: 🎨 chroma.js: Zero Dependency Color Conversion Library
articles.description: I love the simple but suitably colorful documentation this library has. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Gregor Aisch

articles.description: Some Node.js security releases are anticipated next Tuesday (Feb 6.)
TIL: The pnpm project maintains a frequently updated benchmark of package managers (well, npm, pnpm and Yarn, anyway.)
🏀 Bouncy Ball shows a live comparison of 22 ways to animate a bouncing ball in the browser. Most are JS-based and show the code.
Porffor is an experimental, ahead-of-time JS to WASM compiler.
htmx 2.0.0-alpha1 – There's a draft 1.x→2.x migration guide showing what will be affected (not a lot).
Puppeteer 21.10.0 – Node.js API for Chrome - now with experimental browser.debugInfo.
Neutralinojs 5.0 – Lightweight cross platform desktop app framework.
Primate 0.28, Prisma 5.9, Ember 5.6, Pixi.js 7.4

articles.title: Apple's Big Changes to iOS, Safari, and the App Store in the European Union
articles.description: Sweeping changes are on the way for users of iOS, Safari, and the App Store in the EU, though developers worldwide will need to be aware of the changes too. Of particular note to frontend developers will be the introduction of alternative browser engines (i.e. non-WebKit powered browsers) starting with iOS 17.4. However, it isn't all going to be plain sailing...
articles.author: Apple

articles.title: Web Components in Earnest
articles.description: A great walk through the journey behind building an app using Web Components and JavaScript — the author really shows off the realities of going all in with Web Components. The example app is simple, but complete all the same.
articles.author: David Bryant Copeland

articles.title: Highlight Text When a User Scrolls Down to That Piece of Text
articles.description: Here’s how to create a neat animated text highlight effect that triggers based on a scroll-driven CSS class. No JavaScript required.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: CSS Blurry Shimmer Effect
articles.description: Yair shares a step-by-step explanation of how this curious blurry shadow effect comes together, using a combo of masks, gradients, and the backdrop-filter property. CodePen demo.
articles.author: Yair Even Or

articles.title: Going Beyond Pixels and (r)ems in CSS - Relative Length Units Based on Font
articles.description: Brecht invites us to take a little journey with him in to “the wonderful world of <length> units in CSS".
articles.author: Brecht De Ruyte

articles.title: A Configurable Switch using Modern CSS Techniques
articles.description: Leaning on techniques such as :has(), container queries, logical properties and custom properties.
articles.author: Andy Bell

articles.title: ▶  Debugging Fetch Priority
articles.description: A quick talk about the Large Contentful Paint metric, and how to improve it with the Fetch Priority API.
articles.author: Chrome for Developers

articles.title: ▶  The Evolution of Page Speed
articles.description: A ~20-minute look at what Page Speed is, how we manage and optimize it, how it has changed over time, and what 2024 may have in store.
articles.author: Matt Zeunert (DebugBear)

articles.title: The Coding Train
articles.description: Eric Meyer recently put this on my radar — it’s an ongoing, delightful beginner-friendly learning resource, covering things like WebGL, JavaScript, ML, APIs, and more. Plenty of challenges to take on, and great videos to follow along with. (Sidebar: how fun is the branding here?)
articles.author: Daniel Shiffman

articles.title: 'Please, Don’t Force Me to Log In'
articles.description: “The current accelerating trend of requiring accounts and logins for everything has to stop”.
articles.author: Juha-Matti Santala

articles.title: The Web Accessibility Framework for Organizations
articles.description: A resource explaining this new Web Accessibility Framework and how you can go about using it to help improve the approachability and availability of projects at an organizational level. There’s a good related read here from Jay Pope explaining why it was created.
articles.author: Whitney Lewis

articles.title: 🅰 Find and Try Variable Fonts
articles.description: This site isn’t new, but continues to be a handy resource for both finding and trying out a growing collection of variable fonts, now supported by nearly all modern browsers. There's over 350 fonts on display now.
articles.author: Nick Sherman

articles.title: unlazy: A Universal Lazy Loading Library for Placeholder Images
articles.description: It's framework-agnostic and intended to be used alongside loading="lazy" to provide temporary placeholder images as a page loads.
articles.author: Johann Schopplich

articles.title: Autosize Textarea: A Web Component for Auto-Resizing textarea Elements
articles.description: This is one way to do this, but you could also opt for this pure CSS solution from a few years back.
articles.author: andrico karoulla

articles.title: WebGPU-Kit
articles.description: This is a minimal webGPU toolkit bringing together a collection of libraries that “make it easy to build high-performance, cross-platform, web-based graphics applications”. GitHub repo.
articles.author: John Beresford

articles.title: Palettify: An Interactive Playground to Customize and Preview UI Themes
articles.description: Currently supports MUI and shadcn-ui for the components and you can customize primary/secondary colors, accents, borders, cards, popovers, and others, before exporting as CSS variables.
articles.author: Mehdi Ben Hadj Ali

articles.title: ASCII Theater: Stream Text-Based Movies in Your Terminal
articles.description: Putting copyright angles aside briefly, this is a neat experiment. Movies meet ASCII art in a bit of terminal fun. Want to give it a go? Grab the popcorn and run this at your terminal: ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no watch.ascii.theater .. then q to quit. (Note: We've had issues with it timing out, but the site and its aesthetic are worth experiencing nonetheless.)
articles.author: MSCHF
